In conclusion, I believe living in the countryside in 2025 isn't only better for your health but will also make economic sense. 

The initial move might require significant effort, the life you create in this setting can be much more fulfilling and meaningful.

Much 💛,
Culture

And this is just my opinion, but being closer to nature can make you feel closer to something greater, whether you call it God, the universe, or just a spiritual connection. 

There's a tangible link between all living things that you can sense more vividly in the countryside.
Nature heals; this isn't just proven by science but something many of us have personally experienced.

The best part is that you'll feel better and live a happier, healthier life. 

Waking up to the sounds of nature, being close to the earth, as opposed to waking in a concrete jungle surrounded by pollution and fast food culture.

This trend provides an opportunity to decentralize populations and establish more self-sustaining communities in previously overlooked rural areas.

But that's not even the best part…

Speaking of emerging technologies, AI will gradually replace many white-collar jobs, which were typically concentrated in urban centers. 

This shift signals a bright future for tangible crafts over digital presentations. 

Craftsmanship is making a significant comeback.

With a good internet connection and some land, numerous opportunities for income generation and small businesses open up. 

Starlink, by the way, has made this scenario more feasible.
Additionally, there are opportunities to cater to urban dwellers, from selling organic honey at farmers' markets to offering rural retreat experiences on your land.

While there's an initial startup cost, in the long run, living in a small countryside community offers many entrepreneurial opportunities. 

Selling goods and providing services to a smaller audience, less competition and, more importantly, foster more genuine human connections.

From eggs to pickles to willow baskets, your imagination is the only limit.

Since people in the countryside are less dependent on urban goods and infrastructure, there's a significant opportunity to identify and fulfill local needs.

First off, you have the opportunity to grow things. 

Not only can this reduce costs by decreasing grocery bills, but it can also become a revenue stream.

In fact, there's a plethora of items you can produce in the countryside that the local community can appreciate.

Commuting is still possible, but keep in mind that maintaining a rural property can be time-consuming.

With that disclaimer out of the way, here's why, in my opinion, a rural lifestyle is far superior to its urban counterpart.

The first thing that comes to mind is the slower pace of life. 

There are more "chores" to manage (which can be beneficial, more on that later), suggesting you might prefer a job that can be done online or take an entrepreneurial approach to income generation.

What I've described is commonplace for many: go to work, attend after-work events, socialize, and then "recuperate" over the weekend by ordering in and watching shows or playing games. Does this sound familiar?

Now, let’s explore how living in the countryside differs.

Although it's more expensive, the convenience compensates by freeing up more time for entertainment.

But what if that was a trap?

Living in a city center is incredibly convenient. You can order food when you’re tired, meet new people daily, find a job quickly, and avoid long commutes. 

You also have immediate access to a wealth of cultural events.

In 2025, Is It Better to Live in the Countryside or in the City?

That’s the question fellow shibe @DogeRetweet recently asked me.

Here's my very biased and subjective opinion… 🙂
